question: wipes his eyes, a horn honks. He looks toward the sound. The ashes of a colleague, I'm taking them to his family. If you wish to open it, please be careful. seems intent on the map, its changing times and distance. He checks his watch - the countdown has gone from 20 to three hours and 32 minutes as Nekhorvich is mesmerized by the descending seconds whipping by.
answer: You keep staring at that watch as if your life depended on it, Doctor..

question: Well, yes. I suppose I am a bit anxious.
answer: They're ready and waiting. You'll soon be with old friends.

question: I'm with an old friend now, Dmitri.
answer: Sorry it couldn't be under happier circumstances.

question: Yes, I'm sorry too.. 'You're sorry and I'm sorry..' - you do know Gradski thought the world of you.
answer: He was quite a man. Did he know before the end you two had succeeded?

question: Yes, he knew. Just..
answer: ..not in time to save him.

question: No. After you've lived with Chimera for twenty hours, nothing can save you. Not even...Bellerophon.
answer: You carry them together? Safely?

question: Yes, and you'll get us to a safe place with them, thank god!..left to my own devices, I'm an old fart too inept to read a railroad timetable!.. ..it seems we have a problem, Dmitri.
answer: You keep calling me Dmitri. You really shouldn't.

question: You're not Dmitri?
answer: - no.

question: If I let you know where I'm going - Do you know me?
answer: No. Should I?

question: No. You just looked as if you did.
answer: No. Just as if I'd like to.

question: Oh. Well. I think that can be arranged.
answer: Not tonight. Bad timing. Sorry -

question: There's not enough time in the world for any of it to be bad.
answer: Look, it's either you or the rent and I don't mind telling you it's not an easy choice.

question: What if I pay the rent?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Uh-huh?
answer: Go find the wealthy lady you came with and next time we meet - I'll pay your rent. Now bugger off. Mmmm.

question: Decisions, decisions.
answer: What are you doing here?

question: Think you're the only one who can pick a lock?
answer: I see. You're not just another pretty face..

question: I take it you prefer tenors.
answer: Would you mind if I'm on top?

question: Damn it! Find what?
answer: His ex-wife's Bulgari necklace that goes up for auction Tuesday.

question: - right..where is it?
answer: Far right.

question: Where's the bloody -
answer: - torque wrench.

question: - this is very disconerting..
answer: Hey, you put me here. I just do what I'm told.

question: - right..
answer: I wouldn't do that.

question: Do what?
answer: That. Well, Senor de l'Arena the goods news is that the heat sensors were activated. But Miss Nordoff-Hall, my associate - - did feel that she had rather too long to work on the safe before they triggered the alarm, isn't that right Miss Hall?

question: Oh yes. Absolutely. Much too long I should yes.
answer: Under the circumstances I think we would recommend re-setting the senors to respond to a lighter load. How do you feel about forty kilos, Miss Hall?

question: Indeed.
answer: Well, Senor de l'Arena, there's no reason to disrupt your party any longer. we have some further concerns about the disposition of your security guards, which you'll receive in our written report by fax in the morning, hard copy to follow. Shall we?

question: The necklace? I'm missing something here, aside from a 500,000 pound necklace. Even after I botched the job, I could've walked out of there with the bloody thing.
answer: At least you walked.

question: If you weren't going to let me get away with it, why did you let me go thru with it?
answer: Wanted to see how good you were. I'm hoping we might work together.

question: May I say something, no offence? You look like a gigolo, you sound like a thief, you act like a cop - what the bloody hell do you have in mind?
answer: Working under adverse conditions. Highly adverse conditions.

question: Sounds smashing. I'm in. Muchacho, mi carro, por favor! Now be serious. You couldn't possibly want me off tonight's performance..
answer: You didn't do that badly.

question: You're apologizing for me? Quite the gentleman..
answer: Not really. I triggered the alarm.. Hey, the Bulgari job last week was flawless. And I've always been partial to pale yellows.

question: I don't do laundry, or put up with cheeky bastards who set me up on their territory so they can poach on mine. Hola..
answer: Hi. Would you mind slowing down?

question: Where did you get this number? I don't even have it!
answer: Pull over and listen to me, will you? Just listen..

question: Listen to what?
answer: I need your help and I thin you can use mine.

question: Your help? What are you talking about?
answer: Scotland Yard, Interpol, every Dutch authority. I can make them go away.

question: Oh bloody hell. You're a spy.
answer: I deserved that. Slow down, slow down.

question: Uh-oh.
answer: No!

question: Oh..oh..
answer: Don't look down. Just..look at me. That's it..that's it..

question: What's you name?
answer: Ethan Hunt.

question: Well, Ethan Hunt, what is it you want to talk to me about?
answer: ...more than I thought..

question: Awfully short notice..
answer: Care to wait a decent interval?

question: Who wants to be decent?..
answer: So what've you got against spooks?

question: When they've got your recruiting technique? Not a thing.
answer: Oh. Well..this isn't exactly by the book.

question: They've got a book for this?
answer: They've got a book for everything.

question: The only other spook I knew was a liar. Charming but absolutely incapable of telling the truth. He'd lie about his favorite color. But then I reckon it's an occupational hazard. All spies really do is conceal the truth and tell lies.
answer: Not revealing information doesn't necessarily make someone a liar.

question: That's not the point. In the end what spies rely on is the one thing they think they know that you don't.
answer: Which is?

question: That they're lying.
answer: So where did I got right?

question: You're not a liar. Or you're an awfully good one.. ..this thing these blokes pinched..
answer: I don't know that they 'pinched' it. Don't even know that they're blokes.

question: Well, then, what I am I doing here? I assume I'm meant to be some sort of thief-to catch-a-thief..
answer: So do I. Sort of.

question: Spoken like a spook..you ever afraid?
answer: Of what?

question: Ask a question, you get an answer!..
answer: Damn, you're beautiful.

question: That's because I'm on my back.
answer: I don't think so. Are you gonna be here a while? I'll pick'em up on my way out, okay?

question: I don't think so. Are you gonna be here a while? I'll pick'em up on my way out, okay?
answer: Fetival's a pain in the ass. Honoring saint by setting'em on fire. Sit down, sit down.

question: Sorry I didn't let you know where I was.
answer: Don't be. Wouldn't be on vacation if you did.

question: Well. You're sorry and I'm sorry.
answer: Why did you phrase it like that?

question: Like what?
answer: 'You're sorry and I'm sorry.'

question: You gotta be kidding.
answer: Well, Dmitri! How are you?..

question: ..I'm fine..and you?
answer: I'm fine..

question: I'm fine and you're fine..
answer: I'm fine too.. I'm fine and you're fine - do you remember, dear fried, how you got Sergei and I to repeat those lines from Dr. Strangelove and we gave you the name of that silly Soviet Premier because we didn't know your name?..In those days, you not only saved our lives, you saved our sanity. 'Now, then Dmitri - we have this little problem'

question: Let me ask you something. You have any idea what the hell he's talking about?
answer: An idea, yeah.

question: Like?
answer: Like it's a good idea to pick him up in a hurry. And a bad idea to fly him on a commercial carrier. So let's get on with it. He's still in Sydney?

question: Dr. Vladimir Nekhorvich is dead. So is his colleague, Gradski, but that happened earlier. We had Nekhorvich on a flight from Sydney that crashed in the Rockies..
answer: If he didn't want to go anywhere without me, how did you get him on the flight?

question: You were there.
answer: slowly looks up at Swanbeck.

question: When I couldn't find you, I had to replace you. Sean Ambrose was the obvious choice. He double you, what? Two, three times?
answer: Twice.

question: What did you think of him?
answer: You know we had reservations about each other. Isn't it a little late in the day to be asking me that?

question: Not necessarily. Airline record list Captain Harold Macintosh as the pilot for Flt 2207. as far as the media and all governmental agencies are concerned, Captain Macintosh died on the flight, but in fact he missed it. He did, however make the next flight - in cargo, stuffed into a rather small suitcase considering his size.
answer: So there's one thing we know Ambrose doesn't.

question: Then you do think it was Ambrose.
answer: Whatever Nekhorvich was carrying Sean wanted and he wanted to conceal the fact that he took it.

question: Enough to kill Nekhorvich and two hundred innocent passengers?
answer: Sean feels he hasn't done the job unless he leaves a lot of hats on the ground.

question: The question is why? What was this Chimera Nekhorvich was carrying?
answer: Right now only Ambrose knows that.

question: In any case, you've got to recover Chimera and bring it to us.
answer: In order to do that, I've got to figure out how he plans to make money with it.

question: - right. In fact since the plane went down our banking sources have confirmed a marked increase in the stock pilling of cash in terrorists accounts.
answer: 'Terrorists?'

question: Well you know Nekhorvich's history. You're the one who got him out of the Soviet Union was it still in bio- weapon business.
answer: If that's what you're thinking Ambrose would have set up a bidding situation with any number of buyers before he got on the plane. Locating him in time to stop something like that -

question: - is where Miss Hall comes in.
answer: Excuse me?

question: Miss Hall and Ambrose had a relationship which he took very seriously. She walked away and he's wanting her back ever since. We believe she's our surest and quickest way of location him.
answer: And then what?

question: Then makes sure she continues to see him. Gets him confide in her and report to you.
answer: You made it sound as if I was recruiting her for her skills as a thief.

question: Well, then I mislead you. Or you made the wrong assumption. Either way we're asking her to resume a prior relationship, not do anything she hasn't already done.
answer: She's got no training for this kind of thing.

question: Go to bed with a man and lie to him? She's a woman. She's got all the training she needs.
answer: I don't think I can get her to do it.

question: You mean it'll be difficult.
answer: Very.

question: Well it's not mission difficult, Hunt. It's mission impossible. Difficult should be a walk in the park for you. If you can think of a quicker way to get to Ambrose, you're welcome to try. Oh, by the way, you might want to take a look at these..if you have any further qualms about getting her to do the job.
answer: Yes. They're very nice..

question: Yes. They're very nice..
answer: carefully places the little Minolta on a glass-topped coffee table. She's beautifully pulled together, the safehouse has the lights low, flamenco music playing, and when she walks out onto the balcony Ethan sees the candlelit table and a bottle of champagne chilling. There's a light breeze the fire from the burning effigies throwing smoke and flame all over the city. What's the population of Seville any idea?

question: Five, six-hundred thousand.
answer: There's nearly 2 million in London.

question: And six billion in the world.
answer: That's lot of people out there..how many of them, I wonder, are capable of something like that?

question: Sean Ambrose, for one.
answer: Right... Not that it matter much but..I seem to recall you staying something like, 'I was hoping we could work together.'

question: This wasn't what I had in mind, Nyah.
answer: But it is what you'd like me to do. so tell me to do it..

question: Go and insinuate yourself back into Sean's life.
answer: I'd like a little more conviction..

question: So would I. But it's not mine to give.
answer: You've either got it or you don't. Let your conscience be your guide?

question: Something like that.
answer: But I don't have a conscience. I'm a bloody thief.

question: You can be a thief and have a conscience.
answer: No. You can be a thief and have a conscience

question: I don't.
answer: Someone in possession of all the facts. Are you telling me I have to do this?

question: Generally, I don't favor coercing someone. Not when there's a chance my life could end up in their hands.
answer: And that's the only reason?

question: Can you think of a better one?
answer: Not me. I was just hoping you might..or that..somehow in the course of business this got personal as well as physical.

question: Look, would it make you feel better if I didn't want you to do this?
answer: Much.

question: Then feel better!..
answer: Sean will never be anything but suspicious if he picks up some sort of 'yoo-hoo-I'm- not-nad' message. Not after the way we broke up.

question: What wouldn't make him suspicious?
answer: Probably that I needed him in some urgent way..destitute - in serious trouble..the kind I couldn't possible sort out myself..

question: Look, I can't run your arrest in CNN, but I guarantee he's monitoring every law enforcement agency in the world, for what they might be saying about him, if nothing else - he's got the ability and, we assume, the desire to get you out of there.
answer: This doesn't seem to be accomplishing much.

question: Well, I mean it's not a total loss. It is keeping a very capable thief off the street..
answer: Very funny..maybe he has heard and doesn't want to know. Maybe he's lost interest. What lawyer?

question: Well, here we go. Stop and look for something in you purse..kneel down..
answer: Limo's waiting.

question: - Ambrose will have counter-surveillance second to no one's. When and if he contacts you, push this button before you actually end up under his roof it'll scramble your transmission to us.
answer: When will you be there?

question: Before you are.
answer: How can you possibly? I've got to get right on the plane. I'm leaving now.

question: You don't trust me.
answer: Oh, I do. But as we know I'm a very poor judge of character.

question: He's got you on Qantas flight 2735. It's going to be delayed.
answer: Yes?

question: You'll be fine. I'm going to lose you.
answer: Ethan, you take care of yourself, I'll take care of myself because if push comes to shove, I'm gonna bail - and without giving two week notice.

question: Not much luggage.
answer: I left in a bit of a hurry. I'm terribly grateful, Sean.

question: How grateful?
answer: Well that depends.

question: On what.
answer: How hard you had to work to get me out of there..how in the world did you ever find me?

question: How I usually find you, Nyah.
answer: How do you that.

question: Magic...
answer: Ahh..

question: What you got there, mate?
answer: A myth..just a myth...shouldn't you be checking out their countersurveillance?

question: Well you know his blokes'll place the OSCOR in his annex, where else if you're pinpointing transmitters, video signals, covert chip cameras, anything radiating, oscillating..
answer: ..or hard wired..

question: Your room.
answer: Mmmm.

question: And my room?
answer: Thought you could use a little something to wear.

question: No changing room?
answer: grips her wrist, the flimsy Armani dangling in the air.

question: Did you say something?
answer: leaning on an elbow, looking down. I said you're beautiful, Nyah.

question: Only because..it's spring..chalk it up - to spring fever.
answer: Won't do, love. It's not spring. It's nearly autumn..You're in Oz. everything's upside down and backwards here.

question: We'll need this at the track. Well then. Sorted.
answer: Not everything. Why do you think she's really here?

question: From her point of view or mine?
answer: Wasn't exactly gagging for it when she left you six months ago..The question is, do you trust her?

question: One considers her timing, of course - getting nicked within a week of the plane going down. Suggestive, even borderline suspicious, but hardly conclusive.
answer: Well, you've thorough about it, at any rate.

question: Tell me, Hugh. You don't exactly hang on Nyah's every word and gesture, do you? Fairly ratty nail, that.
answer: Sean..

question: You're not scrutinizing any casual shrug for some hair-splitting nuance, are you?
answer: Sean, please..

question: Suppose she is some sort of Trojan horse sent in by IMF to spy in us, why should I deny myself the pleasure of a ride or two? Or don't you think I can learn more from her than she can from me?
answer: I do!..

question: Now Hugh, you must realize that some of us have the burden of sex to deal with..and my dear chap. I may or may not know why she thinks she's here, but I'm willing to take the risk, because Hugh, I am gaging for it.. You won.
answer: I suppose I did.

question: What made you pick that nag? She'd never won a bloody thing.
answer: 'Thief in the Night?'

question: Say no more. I'm off to grab a drink. Still favor Bellinis?
answer: Pardon me?

question: How's it going? Everything okay?
answer: Just like old times.

question: Just like old times?
answer: Just about..

question: Tell me who you've run into at Ambrose's.
answer: Near as I can tell, there's at least a half-dozen other blokes about the place. Maybe more. Hugh Stamp, an old mate of Sean's, is the only one I recognize, bit of a creep and then some..

question: We know him. He's over your left shoulder, looking right at you as you go on..
answer: - Michael, his driver's an Aussie, new to me. Then there's the blokes in the annex at the back of the house.

question: Have you met them?
answer: Annex is strictly off limits to me and they never come to the main house, Michael even takes their meals to them all but shoves them under the door.

question: Bids from possible Chimera buyers -- to prove that as of the date on the newspaper those bids are back up by earnest money --
answer: Looks like Ambrose is showing McCloy how to use a digital camera..

question: Whatever McCloy's looking at, he's not happy about.
answer: Ambrose just pulled the memory card out of the digital camera and put it into an envelope, put it in his inner left jacket pocket...

question: Left jacket pocket?
answer: Roger that.

question: Confirm. Left jacket pocket.
answer: Left jacket pocket confirmed.

question: approaches the door thru which Nyah had gone and starts to open it - only to have the door slammed in his face and on his bandaged finger by Billy, in a track usher's uniforms.
answer: Sorry about that, mate, that must've really - aggrhh!..

question: Say again?
answer: Aggrhh-aggrhh-aggrhh...

question: Whatever you're about in future, watch your step. Never know who you might run into... Where's the loo then?
answer: - aggrhh-aggrhh-aggrhh...

question: To Australia. It's made so many convicts feel at home. Here's hoping it does the same for you..
answer: Sean, there's something I've been meaning to talk to you about... Isn't going to be easy for me to say.

question: Then don't say it.
answer: I don't know what to do about you, Sean. I'm more than a bit muddled. I need time.

question: To do what?
answer: Sort it all out.

question: And you're going to have time. There's been a change of plans.
answer: A change of plans?

question: Yes. We won't be able to have dinner tonight. Something's come up. I hope you don't mind.
answer: Oh, no, not at all. Maybe just a bit.

question: Ulrich will be about. He'll look after you.
answer: Lovely.

question: George. George. George. regains consciousness. He's got tubes coming out of every orifice and is contained in the equivalent of a plastic bubble. Drenched in perspiration and he looks around for a call button. He grips the side of the bed. Bloody room..just..shut your eyes, shut your eyes.
answer: a shimmering blur coming in and out of focus. A visit from an old friend.

question: What's happening here? You're dead!
answer: Fatigued, certainly. But dead is a little extreme. On the other hand, when me dear Gradski had your pulse and blood pressure he has less than ten hours to live.

question: It was in the bloody papers, on the telly..what's this about Gradski?
answer: You are infected with Chimera, my friend.

question: Ulrich?..Ulrich!...
answer: Easy, easy, easy, shhh!

question: Oh Ethan!..
answer: Are you okay?

question: I am now. Get me out of here. Just get me out of here.
answer: It's going to be okay.

question: No use, my friend. The medical staff wants no part of this. Doctors don't fancy the idea of dying any more than anybody else.
answer: How could I possibly be infected?

question: That's exactly what Gradski said - 27 hours before he died. With Chimera, the most minute exposure can be fatal. But then you shouldn't be feeling to ill. not for another three of four hours anyway.
answer: You have Bellerophon.

question: Do I?
answer: You took it! All of it! And what if I need it?

question: 'If?' My, my, my...the five hundred people on Bruny Island that you deliberately infected with Chimera needed it as well.
answer: Oh, please! How was I to know they had to be treated with Bellerophon within twenty hours?

question: By asking me.
answer: You still don't get it, do you? You want to make an omelet, you break a few eggs - I needed to know just how bad the disease was - in the real world, not the lab. And you never know til you try. You thought you were genetically splicing together strains of influenza to create a cure for all influenzas. But I saw you creating a disease so terrible in Chimera that the cure would be priceless.

question: You wanted the disease in order to peddle the cure.
answer: Well, the thought had occurred to me. I needed Chimera in order to peddle Bellerophon. For hero to be appreciated, you need a monster. Now that's not so difficult to understand, is it? Look, time was a shot of penicillin could knock off every bloody bug in the zoo! Not anymore!..have you any idea the R&D money it takes to float one little pissy boutique antibiotic that's barely effective against one strain of one bacterium? If I couldn't makes money killing the microscopic little shits that are out there, you'd help me put one out there I can make on!..there it is. I've confessed. I, John C. McCloy, am in business to make money. Lilly's making billions feeding Prozac to depressed dogs. Pfizer doesn't even know where to put the money they're making on Viagra, and let me tell you that shit didn't do a thing for me even at twice the recommended dose, Jesus, who do I have to screw to get a a break!..now get me out of here, get me treated and let's go back to work!..

question: Get it. Those were two explosions, your van and your safehouse, in case you didn't hear them both -- I believe that means you've also lost a friend.
answer: And you couldn't walk to tell me about it.

question: Hold your fire, dammit!
answer: Fight a bit of a cold..

question: And you're happy about that?
answer: Beats fighting the flu, I'm here to tell you.

question: You know, that was the hardest part of having to portray you. Grinning like an idiot every fifteen minutes.
answer: I would've thought the hardest part was exercising restraint. Curbing that pressing need of your to get your gun off. You were in such a hurry to knock off that 747, you never figured out where the virus really was.

question: I knew where it was.
answer: Oh. then you knew the only way could smuggle the live virus to the CDC scientists in Atlanta was by injecting himself and using his own bloodstream as a Petri dish, doing it inside of twenty hours so he could take the anti-virus and still have it be effective. You knew that while you were knocking him off and destroying the very thing you came for.

question: Stop! Put a sock in it! Hit that bloody gun and you'll spray the bloody virus all over the place!
answer: There it is, guys, the last of it.

question: Yep. You've provided us with a golden opportunity to have both the bug and the bug killer.
answer: What was the top bid?

question: Why, you going to make me a better offer?
answer: Than thirty-seven million pounds? Not really.

question: Somebody's been slipping you our mail. Come on out here, you bad girl.
answer: She doesn't belong here, Sean. Let her go.

question: You're not going to shoot, Sean. Not this bitch. She's worth thirty-seven million pounds.
answer: What did you think you were doing!

question: I wasn't thinking! Just..trying to keep you from getting hurt, that's all.
answer: - you who don't have a conscience.

question: I guess I lied..You can't get both of us out of here, can you?
answer: No.

question: Then you'll have to kill me before it's too late. Before I start killing people.
answer: No.

question: I'm infected with Chimera. You know you don't have a choice. Just do it now.
answer: We've got 19 hours and 57 minutes before you start killing anybody. I'll get Bellerophon into your system by then. Just stay alive. I'm not gonna lose you.

question: We've got 19 hours and 57 minutes before you start killing anybody. I'll get Bellerophon into your system by then. Just stay alive. I'm not gonna lose you.
answer: 'Dreaming of Birds and Flying Fox,' 'Bushfire Dreaming,' 'Wind Dreaming,' -- oddly appropriate -

question: Not yet. We did manage to pull any sensitive equipment and material out of our safehouse wreckage.
answer: We could lock down passport control and all ports of authority, but that won't stop Ambrose, and beyond him, we don't know who else we're looking for -- all terrorist bank accounts of which we're aware are stable. No deposits, no withdrawals. Therefore no suspects.

question: We think we've got our finger on the buyer.
answer: Do you? Even assuming you're able to prevent Ambrose selling Chimera, you've now got an additional problem. You destroyed all of Chimera at Biocyte. If Ambrose is going to sell Chimera now, he'll have to do it by taking a pint or so of Miss Hall's blood to market.

question: Yes, I believe that's right.
answer: But that leaves another seven or eight pints of Chimera.

question: You mean that leaves Miss Hall.
answer: Yes, I believe that's right. Now my understanding is that 20 hours after exposure, the victim becomes infectious. Highly infectious. You noted the time of exposure? - good. Then if you manage to get hold of Ambrose, and obtain what he's got, you've got - - 8 hours 57 minutes and twenty-three seconds to destroy the largest remaining source of Chimera on earth.

question: She sacrificed herself..
answer: Brave girl. If you can get hold of Bellerophon with the time limit, you may spare her the ultimate sacrifice. But in either case you've got less than nine hours to kill her or cure her. After that it's out of our hands and a matter of worldwide material law. And Hunt. However you obtain it, we want you to preserve a sample of Chimera. Bring it back alive. Something else?

question: Aren't you even curious? About why she did it?
answer: No. I can't afford to be curious. And neither can you, Hunt..

question: Feel like pleading for your life?
answer: Not as much as you feel like hearing it.

question: God damn it, Nyah! Why did you do it? Why did you save that bastard?
answer: If it'll make you feel any better I won't do it again.

question: If it'll make you feel any better, you're going to take a lot of Aussies with you and make me a lot of money.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Bellerophen? No time at all once I've got it.
answer: Good. Biocyte stock is just a week or two away from going through the roof.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: An outbreak of Chimera.

question: Where?
answer: In downtown Sydney for a start. -- now here's the way it's going to work..Wallis, the shares outstanding are..

question: Which means, Mr. McCloy, we have to get our hands on four hundred and eighty thousand options. We'll borrow your thirty million to buy those options. Your stock's never sold above thirty-one dollars a share. We'll agree to buy at fifty.
answer: Outrageous. I won't let you take control of my company.

question: Sit down. You'll be a billionaire. Better than being broke. I've got terrorists and other pharmaceutical companies standing in line. Ball's in your court, Mr. McCloy. Run that bastard down. We're running short on time, Mr. McCloy. We've got to conclude our business.
answer: Yes, start the transfer.

question: Ethan, the computer's up. I've got Nyah. She's moved out of the city.
answer: Luther, say again.

question: She's on the North Head Bluff - approaching the cliffs. One klick away.
answer: Copy. She's only got twenty-eight minutes left. Track ahead and pick her up.

question: We won't be able to cover you.
answer: You're breaking up. Track ahead and pick her up. You've got me on GPS. Bring her to me.

question: Sorry, Ethan. I don't quite know where to begin. Any suggestions?
answer: You'd like me to conduct my own debriefing.

question: Why not? You've done just about everything else on this operation.
answer: I'd thank you -- but I'm not sure that was a compliment.

question: Of course it was. Anyone whose operations requires the level of disinformation that yours do, is bound to get a little flak here and there. You try flogging the stories on CNN I've had to come up with about what's been going on around here the last few days. At any rate, it's been most instructive -- what they'll swallow, or what they'll broadcast with a straight face. Miss Hall's blood, it appears, has absolutely no elements of the Chimera virus. Not even antibodies.
answer: Yes, I gathered as much.

question: And the only other remaining sample was in the canister you recover from Ambrose.
answer: Yes.

question: And that appears to have been destroyed. It also contained the anti-virus, Bellerophon.
answer: Well, Bellerophon, it turns out, was only really effective against Chimera.

question: But you were under specific instructions to bring back a living sample of the Chimera virus. I'd be very interested to know how, after you'd managed its recovery intact, it subsequently got destroyed.
answer: By fire. That's the best way, really.

question: So you didn't fail mission, you simply changed it.
answer: No, I don't. But in this case -

question: In this case, it wasn't a bad idea. In face, it was a pretty damn good idea. Just don't make a habit of it. And, as for Ms. Hall, in light of her efforts, her criminal records will certainly be expunged. I'm assuming you approve.
answer: I do.

question: Where is she now, by the way? Do you know?
answer: I don't. No exactly.

question: Well, Hunt, what are your plans?
answer: Not sure. Some sort of vacation. I'll let you know where I'm going.
